entry.title: Time-series Forecasting with Generative AI: Integrating HANA AI Toolkit with Joule in SAP Build Code
entry.content:
Introduction

In the era of AI-first development, embedding intelligence into business applications is no longer optional‚Äîit's expected. As an application developer working on SAP BTP, I was recently tasked with enhancing our Sales Refunds Analysis application with a forecasting component. The challenge? I‚Äôm not a data scientist.

But thanks to the HANA AI Toolkit and Joule, SAP Build Code‚Äôs AI co-pilot, I was able to build a robust forecasting solution‚Äîwithout needing deep expertise in machine learning.

In this blog, I‚Äôll walk you through how I used a simple slash command /hana-ai to interact with the HANA AI Toolkit via Joule, and how this integration empowered me to build, evaluate, and deploy a forecasting model in just a few conversational steps.

What is the HANA AI Toolkit?

The Generative AI Toolkit for SAP HANA Cloud is a powerful suite of tools designed to simplify the use of SAP HANA‚Äôs machine learning and vector capabilities. It includes:

  • Conversational agents for building forecasting models
  • Tools for selecting and applying ML algorithms
  • SmartDataFrame interface for natural language data exploration
  • Vector and embedding services
  • Code generation components for SAP HANA Cloud scenarios

Meet Joule: Your AI Co-Pilot in SAP Build Code

Joule is SAP Build Code‚Äôs generative AI assistant, designed to help developers write, generate, and integrate code faster. With the new /hana-ai slash command, Joule can now directly interact with the HANA AI Toolkit‚Äîbringing ML capabilities into the hands of every developer.

My Use Case: Forecasting Sales Refunds

Here‚Äôs how I used the integration to build a forecasting model for our Sales Refunds application:

1. Initiating the Forecasting Task

/hana-ai I am tasked to create a forecasting application, do you have any hana-ai tools which can help me with that?

Joule responded with a list of ready-to-use forecasting tools like:

  • additive_model_forecast_fit_and_save
  • automatic_timeseries_fit_and_save
  • intermittent_forecast

‚ÄÉ

2. Exploring the Data

/hana-ai Show me the first 5 rows from SALES_REFUNDS table

Joule fetched the data, helping me understand the structure and values.

‚ÄÉ

3. Generating a Dataset Report

A detailed HTML report was generated, giving me insights into data quality and structure.

‚ÄÉ

4. Time Series Analysis

 
/hana-ai Please analyse and check the time series data in the table SALES_REFUNDS_TRAIN

Joule analyzed the dataset and provided:

  • Stationarity check (KPSS test)
  • Seasonality detection
  • Intermittency level
  • Suggested algorithms and many more details

‚ÄÉ

5. Choosing the Right Algorithm

 
/hana-ai Which time series forecasting algorithm do you suggest?

Based on the data characteristics, Joule recommended the Additive Model Forecast.

‚ÄÉ

6. Building the Forecast Model

 
/hana-ai Build a forecast model and save it as Refunds-ForecastModel

The model was trained and saved with versioning support.

‚ÄÉ

‚ÄÉ

7. Generating Predictions

 
/hana-ai Apply the latest forecast model to the SALES_REFUNDS_PREDICT table

Predictions were stored in a new table, ready for analysis.

8. Visualizing the Forecast

 
/hana-ai Generate a forecast line plot

A visual plot was generated to compare actual vs. predicted values.

‚ÄÉ

‚ÄÉ

9. Evaluating Accuracy

 
/hana-ai Evaluate the forecast accuracy

Joule returned key metrics:

  • MAPE: 8.41%
  • MSE: 16,807,501.57
  • RMSE: 4,099.70

‚ÄÉ

10. Generating CAP Artifacts

 
/hana-ai Generate CAP artifacts for the forecast model

Joule generated and offered to integrate the artifacts directly into my CAP project.

Outcome

With just a few conversational commands, I was able to:

  • Analyze time series data
  • Select the right forecasting model
  • Train and evaluate the model
  • Visualize and integrate the results into my application

All without writing a single line of ML code.

Key Takeaways

  • AI democratization: Developers without ML expertise can now build intelligent features.
  • Conversational development: Joule + HANA AI Toolkit enables natural language-driven workflows.
  • Enterprise-ready: The integration supports versioning, evaluation, and CAP artifact generation.

What‚Äôs Next?

This is just the beginning. With the /hana-ai slash command, we‚Äôre opening the door to a wide range of AI-powered development scenarios‚Äîfrom classification to anomaly detection and beyond.

If you're building on SAP BTP and want to embed intelligence into your applications, give the HANA AI Toolkit and Joule a try. You might be surprised how far a conversation can take you.

entry.title: Top Reasons to Modernize with SAP HANA Cloud ‚Äì Blog #5 in the Series
entry.content:
This is the final chapter in this blog series on the benefits of migrating to SAP HANA Cloud. In each blog, I‚Äôve described key features that offer significant benefits for your organization and can help you build your business case for SAP HANA Cloud.

Although it can be difficult calculating the business value of migrating your database to the cloud, the expertise of independent organizations can be helpful. A recent IDC study[1]  used a specialized business value methodology to assess the benefits of SAP HANA Cloud delivered to participating organizations. IDC concluded that the benefits were worth an annual average of US$13.7 million per organization and that the database enabled a 35% three-year reduction in total cost of ownership.

If you don‚Äôt have time to read this report, I encourage you to complete your own organization assessment using our free tool. In less than five minutes, you‚Äôll receive useful insights that can help you decide your next steps.

 

Let‚Äôs consider two more features of SAP HANA Cloud that can help you realize significant business value: comprehensive security and a complete application development ecosystem.

Comprehensive security

Protecting your data and helping ensure compliance are top concerns for every organization. As business operations and workforces become more distributed, the need to provide secure data access from anywhere in the world intensifies.

SAP HANA Cloud offers robust security features that cover critical data protection areas, including authentication, authorization, user management, data masking, anonymization, and encryption. Because these features are built into the database, you have little or no need for third-party security tools. These capabilities also reduce the administrative effort needed to protect data.

Support for multiple security certifications and standards, such as ISO (International Organization for Standardization) and SOC (Standard Occupational Classification), helps ensure regulatory compliance. Configurable audit policies streamline compliance activities while helping protect your business and your customers. Automated updates to libraries and applications also boost security.

These features help make it faster and simpler to meet your security goals. According to the IDC report, the security teams of organizations that deployed SAP HANA Cloud increased efficiency by 19%. This benefit translates into an average annual business value of $183,016 per organization.

One study participant from the agriculture industry cited the database security standards and policies of SAP HANA Cloud, considering it an extra protective layer to reinforce security. ‚ÄúIf we had an on-premises database, we‚Äôd lack this added protection,‚Äù said the interviewee. ‚ÄúThe entire platform has policies that prevent mistakes. For instance, SAP now requires updates to libraries and applications for security reasons. These requirements from SAP keep us updated and secure.‚Äù

Another participant from the healthcare industry viewed the advanced protection as a financial advantage. ‚ÄúSAP HANA Cloud is a much more secure system that makes data more accessible and applications perform faster,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúThis has helped us meet our customers‚Äô needs much better and has improved our revenue by about five percent.‚Äù

A complete application development ecosystem

Time and resources are tight for your development teams. Demand from business users has never been higher, new use cases are emerging, and the need for different developer skill sets seems to continually grow.

SAP HANA Cloud can help address these challenges with an integrated development ecosystem based on SAP Build solutions. SAP Build offers a comprehensive group of tools that support the full spectrum of no-code/low-code, pro-code, and generative AI development approaches. With SAP Build and SAP HANA Cloud, you can support developers at any skill level with the right tools.

Developers can build intelligent applications that use generative AI and harness their expertise and data. Applications built on SAP HANA Cloud can use intelligent algorithms to process large volumes of data and provide actionable recommendations. SAP HANA Cloud also includes machine learning libraries that help developers build sophisticated analytics applications that augment user expertise. By incorporating AI-driven insights, these applications help you anticipate future trends and predict behaviors, make business decisions faster, and improve business performance.

The IDC report found that these application development capabilities deliver quantifiable business value. IDC estimates that development team productivity spiked by 30% in the surveyed organizations, creating staff time savings of $361,519 per organization.  

SAP HANA Cloud features, such as information libraries, combined with faster performance and easier integrations, helped developers build more complex applications such as those using machine learning and AI. Overall, participants developed or deployed 154% more features and applications annually than they could without SAP HANA Cloud.

One study participant explained the impact of this value on the development team. ‚ÄúSAP HANA Cloud provides developers with more seamless integrations, and it is easy to use,‚Äù the interviewee explained. ‚ÄúThey spend less time writing code because they can reuse code and use the libraries.‚Äù

 

Explore additional SAP HANA Cloud resources

As we‚Äôve seen in this , the advanced features of SAP HANA Cloud offer significant value for organizations like yours. To help you make your business case for SAP HANA Cloud, check out the following resources:

  • What‚Äôs the potential value of SAP HANA Cloud for your organization? Complete a short assessment. 
  • Learn more about SAP HANA Cloud.
  • Discover how moving to SAP HANA Cloud helps you create a foundation for modernization.
  • Explore this guide on building a compelling business case to move your database to the cloud.

 

[1] ‚ÄúThe Business Value of SAP HANA Cloud,‚Äù IDC, sponsored by SAP, April 2025.

entry.title: Open Source - Apache Superset‚Ñ¢ and SAP HANA Comes together to help you
entry.content:
https://superset.apache.org/ 

In today‚Äôs data-driven world, organizations need powerful tools to explore, visualize, and act on their data. Apache Superset‚Ñ¢, an open-source data visualization platform, combined with SAP HANA, a high-performance in-memory database, offers a robust solution for modern analytics.

Documentation

https://superset.apache.org/docs/6.0.0/intro 

Apache Superset Highlights:

  • Open-source and free to use
  • Rich visualization options (bar charts, pie charts, geospatial maps, etc.)
  • SQL Lab for advanced querying
  • Role-based access control and authentication
  • Cloud-native and scalable architecture

SAP HANA Advantages:

  • In-memory computing for real-time analytics
  • Combines transactional and analytical workloads
  • Advanced analytics (predictive, spatial, text)
  • High performance with large datasets
  • Seamless integration with enterprise systems

Together, they enable real-time, interactive dashboards that empower business users and data analysts alike.

Use Cases

  • Sales Dashboards: Real-time revenue tracking across regions
  • Operations Monitoring: Visualize supply chain metrics
  • Finance Analytics: Profitability and cost breakdowns
  • Customer Insights: Behavioral analysis from SAP CRM data

Final Thoughts

Apache Superset and SAP HANA together form a powerful duo for enterprise-grade analytics. With Superset‚Äôs intuitive interface and HANA‚Äôs blazing-fast performance, teams can unlock insights faster and make data-driven decisions with confidence.

entry.title: Partners unveil generative AI applications to solve real-time industry challenges with SAP and AWS
entry.content:
AWS SAP AI Co-Innovation Program

At SAP Sapphire 2025, SAP and Amazon Web Services (AWS) unveiled the AI co-innovation program aimed at assisting partners in developing Generative AI applications to address business challenges. This program integrates advanced GenAI technologies from SAP with Generative AI Services from AWS, complemented by SAP Enterprise Resource Planning (ERP) Data, to facilitate customer implementation journeys.

As a pivotal advancement in the SAP AI co-innovation program, AWS and SAP have established a new cohort in collaboration with SAP‚Äôs well-established Hack2Build initiative. This cohort provides support for the development, testing, and deployment of industry-specific applications. Partners are encouraged to develop industry-focused solutions utilizing AWS generative AI tools and services from Amazon Bedrock, including large language models (LLMs) such as Amazon Nova and Anthropic Claude within AI Foundation on SAP Business Technology Platform (SAP BTP). This enables partners to swiftly develop and deploy AI applications tailored to their customers‚Äô SAP workloads.

Hack2Build

Hack2Build Cohort- September 2025 with AWS

 The new cohort of Hack2Build, an initiative of Partner Excellence Center, SAP Partner Ecosystem Success in collaboration with AI Partner Product Management, SAP Business AI and Amazon Web Services, brought together AI expertise from SAP and AWS and architects to expedite the development of partner Generative AI applications within a seven-day timeframe. Ten partners were selected across various regions as part of this initiative. Experts from SAP and AWS provided support and guidance to the selected ten partners on the chosen use cases. The hack phase commenced on September 22nd and concluded with an impressive demo jam on September 30th.

Partners selected for Hack2Build Cohort with AWS and SAP - September 2025

Hack2Build Cohort: üéâ Winners

 In this blog post, we will delve into the generative AI solutions developed by the winning partners. These solutions leverage the capabilities of Generative AI Hub, a component of SAP AI Core, a service within the SAP Business Technology Platform (SAP BTP). By accessing various Large Language Models (LLMs) on Amazon Web Services (AWS) through the Amazon Bedrock platform, the partners have harnessed the power of generative AI to create innovative solutions.Hack2Build Cohort 2025-Winners' Podium- AWS SAP AI Co-Innovation

üßë‚Äç‚öñÔ∏èüßëüèª‚Äç‚öñÔ∏è Judges

 On September 30, 2025, a distinguished panel of senior leaders from SAP and AWS convened to select three winners from the demo jam.

  • Kamal Arora, Director of Solutions Architecture and AI Innovation at AWS USA
  • Marc-Oliver Klein, Vice President and Head of Partner Product Management and Strategic AI Development Partnerships at SAP SE
  • Stefan Wellner, Vice President of Technology Alliances, Platform and Incubation Partnerships at SAP Business AI Ecosystem at SAP SE
  • Tom Adams, Director of Global Business Consulting and Advisory Partners at AWS USA 

 ü•á Winner: Atos

Atos presented an AI-Powered Supply Chain Disruption Analysis solution that addresses external vulnerabilities in supply chains, particularly unforeseen disruptions. The solution integrates real-time hazard data with SAP metrics to enhance operational resilience. It also integrates SAP BTP services UI5 and CAP applications with AWS AI services, including the Anthropic Claude 4 Sonnet LLM model on Amazon Bedrock. Key features demonstrated include real-time disruption data collection and automated supplier prioritization integrated with SAP S/4HANA systems.

AI-Powered Supply Chain Disruption Analysis by Atos

ü•à1st Runner up - Capgemini

Capgemini demonstrated a GTS smart check solution that seamlessly integrates with SAP GTS and SAP S/4HANA. This solution effectively addresses challenges in import processing, where manual document handling and compliance checks result in delays. The solution significantly reduces import processing time, thereby saving substantial hours annually. This is achieved through the automation of data extraction and comparison from multiple document sources using the Anthropic Claude 4 Sonnet LLM model from Amazon Bedrock.

Capgemini's GTS Smart Check Solution

ü•â2nd Runner up - NTT Data

NTT Data unveiled its Voice Control ERP Assistant, a collaborative solution designed to alleviate the challenges associated with accessing ERP systems on the shop floor. This innovative solution addresses the inherent difficulties faced by workers in navigating unfamiliar ERP systems without disrupting their workflow. By seamlessly integrating SAPUI5 and HANA Cloud, SAP HANA Vector Engine, Generative AI Hub within SAP BTP Services, and Anthropic Claude LLM from Amazon Bedrock, including Amazon Polly for voice interaction, the solution enables hands-free access to ERP data and documentation. Specifically targeting the manufacturing industry, the solution demonstrated substantial business value by enhancing task focus and mitigating employee turnover.

Voice Controlled ERP Assistant by NTT Data

üëèüèº Finalists

We thank all the finalist teams who successfully demonstrated the innovations to the panel of judges, as a part of this Hack2Build cohort.

FinalistsMinimal Viable Product demonstrated
AccentureNavi , a smart delivery scheduling solution focusing on the supply chain's inefficiencies in developing countries
CognizantAsset Unitization AI, addresses manual asset unitization challenges in asset-intensive industries
DeloitteRelationship Management Agent, automates the processing of email queries related to supplier and vendor management
IBMSustainable Buddy, addresses sustainability challenges for better operational transparency and efficiency in Oil & Gas
LTIMindtreeFieldSense.ai, enhances SAP Service and Asset Manager to streamline field service operations, improve safety, and ensure compliance in Utilities and Manufacturing
Phoenix ConsultingAutomated Supplier Invoice Processing, addresses high manual effort and error rates in accounts payable ,supporting Arabic characters and Hindu numerals
Tech MahindraImprove PO extraction  and Sales Order creation process, easing the process of extracting data from challenging invoice formats like blurry or multilingual images.

üôè  Special Thanks

We extend our appreciation to the many AWS and SAP experts , who coached the partners to successfully develop their solutions during this Hack2Build initiative.

‚òû  Next Phase

We anticipate that all participating partners will now proceed to finalize their comprehensive solution within a timeframe of 6 to 8 weeks. SAP and AWS will actively engage with all participating partners to provide support throughout their development process in the upcoming weeks, ensuring that their innovations are prepared for customer deployment.

entry.title: Step-by-Step Guide: Enabling Standard F4 Help for Custom Field created using SAP CFL App
entry.content:
Overview: In SAP, CFL refers to Custom Fields and Logic. It is not a standalone application; rather, it is a Fiori application provided by SAP as a component of S/4HANA Extensibility. The application allows users to incorporate new fields and business logic into standard SAP applications without coding. In this section, we will locate the Custom Fields and Custom Logic tab. Within the Custom Fields tab, we can add our custom fields, while the Custom Logic tab is designated for BAdI implementation, which is currently not in use. For custom logic, we have an additional Fiori application named as Custom Logic.

Introduction: In this blog, we will explore how to add a custom field using the Custom Fields and Logic Fiori application, as well as how to implement standard search help (F4 Help) within that custom field using the SAP Screen Layout of custom created Sub-screen or Main Screen.

Step-by-Step Process:

Step 1 - Open Custom Fields and logic Fiori App.

Step 2 - Press the ‚Äú+‚Äù button located at the top right.

Step 3 - After clicking the ‚Äú+‚Äù button, a pop-up will appear prompting you to enter the appropriate Business Context Id (MM_PURREQN_ITEM) for the corresponding SAP module along with any other necessary fields.

Step 4 - Please choose the correct type from the dropdown menu (such as Text, Code List, etc.). The Text option is solely for input purposes, while the Code List should be used if you wish to assign any fixed values to your field, as other types serve different functions.

Step 5 - Give desired length to the field and click on ‚ÄúCreate‚Äù Button.

Step 6 - It will appear like this on ‚ÄúHome Page‚Äù of the App.

Step 7 - Provide the field label to the field and click on ‚ÄúSave‚Äù and ‚ÄúPublish‚Äù Button.

Step 8 - In the other tabs, you will find the UI specifications, names of CDS Views, details of the Odata Service, API information, and more.

Step 9 - Once you publish your field, it will be incorporated into the standard table of the relevant business context. In my situation, it will appear in the EBAN table with a name that begins with "ZZ1" under an Append Structure.

Step 10 - Custom sub-screen as a Customer Data tab has been created in the ME51N T-code (Create Purchase Requisition Fiori App) where I have added that custom field.

Step 11 - Open the Screen Layout of the corresponding screen via path System > status > Program Name > Screen > Screen Layout.

Step 12 - Double click on the input field and Properties pop-up will appear.

Step 13 - Enter the standard search help name in the search help field of the property pop-up, and you will notice the F4 help added in the custom field.

Step 14 - Search Help Window.

Conclusion: Using the Custom Fields and Logic app in SAP Fiori, we can easily extend standard applications like ME51N by creating custom fields tailored to business needs. By integrating standard search helps into these fields and placing them on a custom sub screen, we enhance usability while maintaining consistency with SAP‚Äôs native behavior. This approach ensures flexibility, upgrade safety, and a smooth user experience‚Äîall without needing deep technical development.

This approach will work when you have custom screen, for standard screen we have an alternative option to utilize CDS views F4 help during the creation of fields via Custom fields and logic Fiori App.

entry.title: Step-by-Step: Implementing Generative AI with SAP HANA Cloud
entry.content:
Introduction:

This blog walks through building an AI Sales Assistant on SAP HANA Cloud calculation views. The assistant enables users to ask natural-language questions such as ‚ÄúWhich product category had the highest sales in Q2?‚Äù and receive contextual answers generated directly from enterprise data.

The solution uses the Retrieval-Augmented Generation (RAG) pattern, where sales transactions stored in HANA are enriched with embeddings and combined with a Large Language Model (LLM) to deliver precise, business-aware responses. This approach extends the analytical power of HANA Cloud with conversational intelligence- effectively bringing AI integration to your calculation views without moving the data out of HANA.

We‚Äôll cover the concepts, high-level architecture, and detailed implementation steps so you can replicate this setup on your own HANA Cloud system and make the most of your existing calculation views.

High Level Architecture:

Key Concepts:

Retrieval-Augmented Generation:

It‚Äôs an AI pattern where a language model (like GPT) is not used in isolation, but is ‚Äúaugmented‚Äù with external knowledge retrieved from a database or document store.

It has two main steps:

  1. Retrieval ‚Äì Find the most relevant documents/data from a knowledge source (e.g., database, embeddings index, vector store).

  2. Generation ‚Äì Pass both the retrieved data + the user‚Äôs query into the LLM so the response is grounded in actual facts instead of just relying on the LLM‚Äôs training data.

SAP HANA Cloud:
The foundation of this project is SAP HANA Cloud. HANA calculation view serves as the source for the RAG (Retrieval-Augmented Generation) application. With the new HANA Cloud Vector Engine, we can now store and query embeddings directly inside HANA eliminating the need for external vector databases. For this setup, we create a dedicated embeddings table to persist vector representations of the sales data.

Flask API:
For the backend, I used Flask, a lightweight Python web framework.Flask allows Python code to be exposed as REST APIs or lightweight web applications. In this project, the Flask API connects to the HANA calculation view, retrieves data, and interacts with the OpenAI API. OpenAI generates embeddings for the data, which are then stored in the embeddings table in HANA Cloud. The same API also handles user prompts: it takes queries from the frontend, searches the embeddings table, and returns contextual answers. 

Streamlit:
The frontend is built with Streamlit, a Python framework for creating simple yet powerful user interfaces. It provides a chat-like interface where users can enter questions. The prompts are passed to the Flask API, which handles retrieval and reasoning. While Streamlit makes prototyping easy, this frontend could also be replaced with SAP Fiori or any Web frontend.

Implementation steps:

Let‚Äôs see step by step on how to develop this framework for existing calculation views.

Prerequisites: Python 3.9+, BAS environment, CF CLI, HANA DB instance, OpenAI API key.

  1. I have two projects in BAS: one containing the HANA calculation views, and the other containing the Flask backend (referred to as the Flask app). Below is the output of the calculation view.

        2.We need to convert the hana data into embeddings and store them in HANA tables. Create embeddings table in HANA cloud. Below is the sql for that. 

CREATE TABLE SALES_EMBEDDINGS (
    TRANSACTION_ID NVARCHAR(50),
    TEXT NVARCHAR(5000),
    EMBEDDING REAL_VECTOR(1536)
);

       3. To generate embeddings using a LLM we need access. In my case i have used LLM from Open AI. Create an account in Open AI and register for Open API key.

       4. Create a python file (eg : generate_embeddings.py) in your flask project to generate embeddings based on your calculation view data and store in HANA cloud table created above. Have your credentials in the env file for testing. Make sure your BAS dev space is in the same region as your HANA cloud instance otherwise connection fails.  This step makes sure we are able to connect to HANA convert calculation view(CV) data into text and generate embeddings for it. Run this file separately and see if data is inserted into HANA cloud table.

import os
from hdbcli import dbapi
from openai import OpenAI
from dotenv import load_dotenv

# Load environment variables
load_dotenv()

# OpenAI client
client = OpenAI(api_key=os.getenv("OPENAI_API_KEY"))

# Connect to SAP HANA Cloud
conn = dbapi.connect(
    address=os.getenv("HANA_HOST"),   # e.g. yourhana.hana.prod-us10.hanacloud.ondemand.com
    port=int(os.getenv("HANA_PORT", "443")),
    user=os.getenv("HANA_USER"),
    password=os.getenv("HANA_PASSWORD")
)

cursor = conn.cursor()

# Fetch sales transactions
cursor.execute("""
    SELECT TRANSACTION_ID, REGION, PRODUCT, SALES_AMOUNT, SALE_DATE 
    FROM schema name."cv_sales_test"
""")
rows = cursor.fetchall()

# 5. Generate embeddings and insert into HANA
for row in rows:
    transaction_id, region, product, sales_amount, sales_date = row
    text = f"Transaction {transaction_id} in {region} sold {product} for {sales_amount} on {sales_date}"

    embedding = client.embeddings.create(
        model="text-embedding-3-small",
        input=text
    ).data[0].embedding

    cursor.execute("""
        INSERT INTO "schemaname"."SALES_EMBEDDINGS" (TRANSACTION_ID, TEXT, EMBEDDING)
        VALUES (?, ?, ?)
    """, (transaction_id, text, embedding))

conn.commit()
cursor.close()
conn.close()

print("Embeddings inserted into SALES_EMBEDDINGS table in HANA Cloud.")

Sales embeddings table output:

       5. Now let's implement RAG on embeddings. Create a new file for RAG query code. This function connects to HANA cloud and fetches stored vector representations of the transactions. The user's question is passed to OpenAI embeddings API and question is converted into numerical vector. We compute cosine similarity between the query embedding and stored transaction embeddings. The top results are combined with the user‚Äôs original question to form a prompt, which is then sent to the LLM to generate a contextual answer.

import os
import json
import struct
import numpy as np
from hdbcli import dbapi
from openai import OpenAI
from sklearn.metrics.pairwise import cosine_similarity
from dotenv import load_dotenv

load_dotenv()


# --------------------------
# Get HANA credentials (VCAP aware)
# --------------------------
def get_hana_credentials(debug=False):
    vcap_services = os.environ.get("VCAP_SERVICES")
    if vcap_services:
        try:
            vcap = json.loads(vcap_services)
            for key in vcap:
                if "hana" in key.lower():  # find any hana service
                    creds = vcap[key][0]["credentials"]
                    if debug:
                        print("Found HANA credentials from VCAP_SERVICES:", creds)
                    return {
                        "host": creds.get("host"),
                        "port": creds.get("port"),
                        "user": creds.get("user"),
                        "password": creds.get("password")
                    }
        except Exception as e:
            if debug:
                print("Error parsing VCAP_SERVICES:", e)

    # fallback to env vars
    creds = {
        "host": os.environ.get("HANA_HOST"),
        "port": os.environ.get("HANA_PORT"),
        "user": os.environ.get("HANA_USER"),
        "password": os.environ.get("HANA_PASSWORD")
    }
    if debug:
        print("Using HANA credentials from environment variables:", creds)
    return creds

# --------------------------
# Run RAG query
# --------------------------

def run_rag_query(user_query, top_k=5, debug=False):

    openai_api_key = os.environ.get("OPENAI_API_KEY")
    if not openai_api_key:
        raise Exception("OPENAI_API_KEY environment variable not set")
    openai_client = OpenAI(api_key=openai_api_key)

    hana_creds = get_hana_credentials(debug=debug)
   
    conn = None
    cursor = None
    try:
        conn = dbapi.connect(
            address=hana_creds["host"],
            port=int(hana_creds["port"]),
            user=hana_creds["user"],
            password=hana_creds["password"]
        )
        cursor = conn.cursor()

        # Fetch embeddings from HANA
        cursor.execute('SELECT TRANSACTION_ID, TEXT, EMBEDDING FROM "schemaname"."SALES_EMBEDDINGS"')
        rows = cursor.fetchall()

        if not rows:
            context = "No transactions available."
        else:
            # Compute query embedding
            embedding_resp = openai_client.embeddings.create(
                model="text-embedding-3-small",
                input=user_query
            )
            query_embedding = np.array(embedding_resp.data[0].embedding, dtype=np.float32)
            query_dim = len(query_embedding)

            texts, embedding_list = [], []
            for row in rows:
                text = row[1]
                blob = row[2]
                if len(blob) < query_dim * 4:
                    continue
                embedding = np.array(struct.unpack('f' * query_dim, blob[:query_dim*4]), dtype=np.float32)
                texts.append(text)
                embedding_list.append(embedding)

            if not embedding_list:
                context = "No valid transactions found."
            else:
                similarities = [cosine_similarity(query_embedding.reshape(1, -1), e.reshape(1, -1))[0][0] for e in embedding_list]
                top_indices = np.argsort(similarities)[-top_k:][::-1]
                context = "\n".join([texts[i] for i in top_indices])

        # GPT completion: summarize transactions
        prompt = f"""
You are a helpful sales analyst assistant.
Based on the following transactions:

{context}

Answer the user's question in **natural language**, summarizing key insights if possible.
Question: {user_query}
Please keep your answer concise.
"""

        response = openai_client.chat.completions.create(
            model="gpt-4o-mini",
            messages=[{"role": "user", "content": prompt}]
        )

        return response.choices[0].message.content.strip()

    except Exception as e:
        return f"Error in run_rag_query: {str(e)}"

    finally:
        if cursor:
            cursor.close()
        if conn:
            conn.close()

 

       6.  Wrap the above RAG query code in a function and use it in Flask. Install Flask if not already available. Now Flask API is directly using RAG logic. Frontend application can call this API and get a response. Ensure the Flask API works locally and returns expected results before deploying to Cloud Foundry.

pip install flask

 

from flask import Flask, request, jsonify
from hdbcli import dbapi
from openai import OpenAI
import numpy as np
import struct
import os
import json
from sklearn.metrics.pairwise import cosine_similarity as sk_cos_sim
from dotenv import load_dotenv

load_dotenv()

app = Flask(__name__)

# --------------------------
# Cosine similarity
# --------------------------
def cosine_similarity(a, b):
    norm_a = np.linalg.norm(a)
    norm_b = np.linalg.norm(b)
    if norm_a == 0 or norm_b == 0:
        return -1
    return np.dot(a, b) / (norm_a * norm_b)

# --------------------------
# Get HANA credentials
# --------------------------
def get_hana_credentials():
    vcap_services = os.environ.get("VCAP_SERVICES")
    if vcap_services:
        try:
            vcap = json.loads(vcap_services)

            # Look for a service whose name includes "hana"
            for service_name, service_defs in vcap.items():
                if service_name.lower() == "hdi_db":
                    creds = service_defs[0]["credentials"]
                    host = creds.get("host")
                    port = creds.get("port")
                    user = creds.get("user")
                    password = creds.get("password")

                    if host and port and user and password:
                        print(f"Using HANA service from VCAP: {service_name}")
                        return {
                            "host": host,
                            "port": port,
                            "user": user,
                            "password": password
                        }
                    else:
                        print(f"HANA service in VCAP missing user/password. Falling back to manual env vars.")

        except Exception as e:
            print(f"Failed to parse VCAP_SERVICES: {e}")

    # Fallback to manual env vars
    print("Using manual HANA_* environment variables")
    return {
        "host": os.environ.get("HANA_HOST"),
        "port": os.environ.get("HANA_PORT"),
        "user": os.environ.get("HANA_USER"),
        "password": os.environ.get("HANA_PASSWORD")
    }

# --------------------------
# RAG query
# --------------------------
#
# " Your RAG Query here"

# --------------------------
# Health check route
# --------------------------
@app.route("/")
def index():
    return "Flask API is running!"

# --------------------------
# Query route
# --------------------------
@app.route("/query", methods=["POST"])
def query_rag_route():
    data = request.get_json()
    user_query = data.get("query", "")
    if not user_query:
        return jsonify({"error": "Query missing"}), 400

    # Run RAG query
    results = run_rag_query(user_query, top_k=5, debug=False)

    # Return in a format that Streamlit expects
    return jsonify({"results": results})

if __name__ == "__main__":
    app.run(debug=True, host="0.0.0.0", port=int(os.environ.get("PORT", 5000)))

Once you run flask API code ,it will start REST API server. It should return "Flask API is running".

http://<your-BAS-workspace-url>:5000/query

        7. Deploy the Flask app on SAP BTP Cloud Foundry and you will see a URL assigned. Deploying it on cloud foundry frees the dependency on BAS dev space and our frontend app can always call the Flask API. Bind it to the HANA service instance so that cloud foundry injects credentials into the app's environment (VCAP_SERVICES) so the running code can connect to HANA. This makes sure our Flask API will have HANA credentials at runtime. After binding check environment and logs.

Check for services and push your app to CF.

cf services
cf push "app name" -f manifest.yml

For binding app to HANA service:

cf bind-service "app name" "hana service"
cf restage "app name"

Verify environment and logs

cf env "your app name"
cf logs "your app name" --recent

Test it using curl. See the response in results section.

       8. For UI, I have implemented using streamlit on my local machine. In Command line run 'pip install streamlit requests' . Run the program file that contains the code. 

Your browser will open at :

http://localhost:8501

 

Type in any question and it will return a contextual response like below.

Key Advantages:

Leverage Existing SAP Data assets- Reuse of existing HDI Containers and calculation views.

Secured and Enabled -  Access to HANA data remains within the SAP security framework.

Scalable and extensible - The architecture can support multiple use cases like Finance, HR, and Logistics.

Enhanced insights - Combines structured data retrieval with natural-language summarization.

Conclusion:

By integrating SAP HANA Cloud with a Large Language Model using the Retrieval-Augmented Generation (RAG) approach, we‚Äôve transformed standard calculation views into an AI-powered sales assistant . This demonstrates how modern AI capabilities can be layered on top of established enterprise data systems, opening the door to smarter, faster, and more interactive business decision-making.

Thank you,

Saravanan Chinnaswamy.

entry.content:
Knowledge GraphÔºà„Éä„É¨„ÉÉ„Ç∏„Ç∞„É©„ÉïÔºâ„Å®„ÅØ„ÄÅÁü•Ë≠òÔºàKnowledgeÔºâ„Çí„Ç∞„É©„ÉïÊßãÈÄ†„ÅßË°®Áèæ„Åô„Çã„Éá„Éº„Çø„É¢„Éá„É´„ÅÆ„Åì„Å®„Åß„Åô„ÄÇ„Éá„Éº„Çø„Çí„Éé„Éº„ÉâÔºàÂÆü‰ΩìÔºâ„Å®„Ç®„ÉÉ„Ç∏ÔºàÈñ¢‰øÇÔºâ„Å®„Åó„Å¶Ë°®„Åó„ÄÅÊÉÖÂ†±Èñì„ÅÆÈñ¢ÈÄ£ÊÄß„ÇíÂèØË¶ñÂåñ„Åó„Åæ„Åô„ÄÇÂæìÊù•„ÅÆRDB„ÅåË°®ÂΩ¢Âºè„Åß„Éá„Éº„Çø„ÇíÁÆ°ÁêÜ„Åô„Çã„ÅÆ„Å´ÂØæ„Åó„ÄÅ„Éä„É¨„ÉÉ„Ç∏„Ç∞„É©„Éï„ÅØÊÑèÂë≥ÔºàSemanticsÔºâ„Çí‰∏≠ÂøÉ„Å´„Éá„Éº„ÇøÈñì„ÅÆÈñ¢‰øÇÊÄß„ÇíÊâ±„Åà„ÇãÁÇπ„ÅåÂ§ß„Åç„Å™ÁâπÂæ¥„Åß„Åô„ÄÇ„Åì„Çå„Å´„Çà„Çä„ÄÅ„Éá„Éº„ÇøÂêåÂ£´„ÅÆÊÑèÂë≥ÁöÑ„Å™„Å§„Å™„Åå„Çä„ÇíÊòéÁ§∫ÁöÑ„Å´Ë°®Áèæ„Åó„ÄÅË§áÈõë„Å™Âïè„ÅÑ„Å´ÂØæ„Åó„Å¶„ÇÇÈ´òÁ≤æÂ∫¶„Åã„Å§ÊüîËªü„Å™ÂøúÁ≠î„ÇíÂ∞é„ÅçÂá∫„Åô„Åì„Å®„ÅåÂèØËÉΩ„Å´„Å™„Çä„Åæ„Åô„ÄÇ

SAP HANA Cloud„ÅØ„ÄÅ„Åì„ÅÆKnowledge Graph„ÇíÊßãÁØâ„ÉªÊ¥ªÁî®„Åô„Çã„Åü„ÇÅ„ÅÆÊ©üËÉΩ„ÇíÊèê‰æõ„Åó„Å¶„ÅÑ„Åæ„Åô„ÄÇÊú¨„Éñ„É≠„Ç∞„Åß„ÅØ„ÄÅHANA Cloud‰∏ä„ÅßKnowledge Graph„ÇíÂà©Áî®„Åô„Çã„Åü„ÇÅ„ÅÆË®≠ÂÆöÊñπÊ≥ï„Å®„ÄÅPython„ÇíÁî®„ÅÑ„ÅüKnowledge Graph„ÅÆÂÆüË∑µÁöÑ„Å™Ê¥ªÁî®‰æã„ÇíÁ¥π‰ªã„Åó„Åæ„Åô„ÄÇ

 

RDF„Å®SPARQL

Knowledge Graph„ÇíË°®Áèæ„Åô„Çã„Åü„ÇÅ„ÅÆ‰ª£Ë°®ÁöÑ„Å™„Éï„É¨„Éº„É†„ÉØ„Éº„ÇØ„Å®„Åó„Å¶RDFÔºàResource Description FrameworkÔºâ„Åå„ÅÇ„Çä„Åæ„Åô„ÄÇRDF„Åß„ÅØ„ÄÅ„Éá„Éº„Çø„Çí‰∏ªË™û (Subject)„ÄÅËø∞Ë™û (Predicate)„ÄÅÁõÆÁöÑË™û (Object)„ÅÆÔºì„Å§„ÅÆÁµÑ (Triple)„ÅßË°®„Åó„Åæ„Åô„ÄÇ

‰æã„Åà„Å∞„ÄÅ„ÄåÊò•Ê®π„ÅØÁå´„ÇíÈ£º„Å£„Å¶„ÅÑ„Çã„Äç„Å®„ÅÑ„ÅÜÈñ¢‰øÇ„ÇíRDF„ÅßË°®„Åô„Å®„ÄÅÊ¨°„ÅÆ„Çà„ÅÜ„Å´„Å™„Çä„Åæ„Åô„ÄÇ

<http://example.org/Haruki> <http://example.org/owns> <http://example.org/Cat> .

„Åì„ÅÆ„Çà„ÅÜ„Å´„ÄÅRDF„Åß„ÅØ„ÄÅÂêÑ„É™„ÇΩ„Éº„Çπ„ÇíURI„Å®„Åó„Å¶Ë°®Áèæ„Åô„Çã„Åì„Å®„Åß„ÄÅ„Éá„Éº„Çø„Çí‰∏ÄÊÑè„Å´Ë≠òÂà•„Åó„Åæ„Åô„ÄÇ„Åü„Å†„Åó„ÄÅÁõÆÁöÑË™û„Å´„Å§„ÅÑ„Å¶„ÅØURI„Å†„Åë„Åß„Å™„Åè„ÄÅ„É™„ÉÜ„É©„É´ÔºàÊñáÂ≠óÂàó„ÇÑÊï∞ÂÄ§Ôºâ„ÇÇË®±ÂèØ„Åó„Åæ„Åô„ÄÇ

„Åì„ÅÆRDF„ÅßË®òËø∞„Åï„Çå„Åü„Éá„Éº„Çø„ÇíÊ§úÁ¥¢„ÉªÊäΩÂá∫„Åô„Çã„Åü„ÇÅ„ÅÆ„ÇØ„Ç®„É™Ë®ÄË™û„Åå SPARQLÔºà„Çπ„Éë„Éº„ÇØ„É´Ôºâ „Åß„Åô„ÄÇSPARQL„Çí‰Ωø„ÅÜ„Åì„Å®„Åß„ÄÅ„ÄåË™∞„ÅåÁå´„ÇíÈ£º„Å£„Å¶„ÅÑ„Çã„ÅãÔºü„Äç„ÅÆ„Çà„ÅÜ„Å™ÊÑèÂë≥ÁöÑÈñ¢‰øÇ„ÇíÁõ¥Êé•„ÇØ„Ç®„É™„Å®„Åó„Å¶Ë®òËø∞„Åó„ÄÅ„Éá„Éº„ÇøÈñì„ÅÆ„Å§„Å™„Åå„Çä„ÇíÊé¢Á¥¢„Åß„Åç„Åæ„Åô„ÄÇ

„Åü„Å®„Åà„Å∞„ÄÅÊ¨°„ÅÆ„Çà„ÅÜ„Å™„ÇØ„Ç®„É™„Åß„ÄåÁå´„ÇíÈ£º„Å£„Å¶„ÅÑ„Çã‰∫∫„Äç„ÇíÊ§úÁ¥¢„Åß„Åç„Åæ„Åô„ÄÇ

SELECT ?person
WHERE {
  ?person <http://example.org/owns> <http://example.org/Cat> .
}

 

SAP HANA Cloud „ÅÆË®≠ÂÆö

„Åæ„Åö„ÄÅHANA Cloud‰∏ä„Å´RDF„Ç∞„É©„Éï„ÇíÊßãÁØâ„Åô„Çã„Åü„ÇÅ„ÅÆ‰∫ãÂâçÊ∫ñÂÇô„ÇíË°å„ÅÑ„Åæ„Åô„ÄÇSAP HANA Cloud„Å´„Åä„ÅÑ„Å¶„ÄÅKnowledge Graph„ÅÆÊ©üËÉΩ„ÇíÂà©Áî®„Åô„Çã„Å´„ÅØ„ÄÅAdvanced Setting„Å´„Åä„ÅÑ„Å¶„ÄÅTriple Store„ÇíÊúâÂäπÂåñ„Åô„ÇãÂøÖË¶Å„Åå„ÅÇ„Çä„Åæ„Åô„ÄÇ

 

Knowledge Graph„ÅÆÊßãÁØâ„Å®Ê§úÁ¥¢

„Åì„Åì„Åã„Çâ„ÅØ‰ª•‰∏ã„ÅÆ„Éñ„É≠„Ç∞„ÇíÂèÇËÄÉ„Å´„ÄÅKnowledge Graph„ÇíÊßãÁØâ„Åó„ÄÅÊ§úÁ¥¢„Åô„ÇãÊâãÈ†Ü„ÇíPython„ÅßÁ¥π‰ªã„Åó„Åæ„Åô„ÄÇ

Semantic Querying with SAP HANA Cloud Knowledge Graph using RDF, SPARQL, and Generative AI in Python

 

Step 1Ôºö„Éá„Éº„Çø„ÅÆÂâçÂá¶ÁêÜ

„Åæ„Åö„ÄÅRDF„Éï„Ç°„Ç§„É´„ÇíË™≠„ÅøËæº„Åø„ÄÅ„Ç∞„É©„Éï„ÇíÂàùÊúüÂåñ„Åó„Åæ„Åô„ÄÇ„Åì„Åì„ÅßË™≠„ÅøËæº„Çì„Åß„ÅÑ„Çã„ÅÆ„ÅØ„ÄÅ„Éã„É•„Éº„É®„Éº„ÇØÂ∏Ç„Åå„Ç™„Éº„Éó„É≥„ÇΩ„Éº„Çπ„Å®„Åó„Å¶ÂÖ¨Èñã„Åó„Å¶„ÅÑ„Çã„Ç≠„É£„ÉÉ„Ç∑„É•„Éï„É≠„Éº‰∫àÊ∏¨„Å´Èñ¢„Åô„Çã„Éá„Éº„Çø„Åß„Åô„ÄÇRDF„Ç∞„É©„Éï„ÅÆ‰ΩúÊàê„Å®Êìç‰Ωú„Å´„ÅØPython„ÅÆ„É©„Ç§„Éñ„É©„É™„Åß„ÅÇ„Çãrdflib„ÇíÂà©Áî®„Åó„Åæ„Åô„ÄÇ

Financial Plan Statements - Cash Flow

from rdflib import Graph, Namespace

# „Ç∞„É©„Éï„ÇíÂàùÊúüÂåñ„Åó„ÄÅRDF„Éï„Ç°„Ç§„É´„ÇíË™≠„ÅøËæº„ÇÄ
g = Graph()
g.parse("rows.rdf", format="xml")

ÂÖÉ„ÅÆ„Éá„Éº„Çø„Å´„ÅØÂ§öÊï∞„ÅÆËø∞Ë™ûÔºàpredicateÔºâ„ÅåÂê´„Åæ„Çå„Å¶„ÅÑ„Çã„Åü„ÇÅ„ÄÅ„Åì„Åì„Åß„ÅØ rowID„ÄÅdscrptÔºàË™¨ÊòéÊñáÔºâ„ÄÅinfl_outflÔºàÂÖ•Âá∫ÈáëÔºâ „Å®„ÅÑ„Å£„ÅüÁâπÂÆö„ÅÆËø∞Ë™û„ÇíÊåÅ„Å§„Éà„É™„Éó„É´„ÅÆ„Åø„Çí„ÄÅÂêçÂâçÁ©∫Èñì„ÇíÊåáÂÆö„Åó„Å¶ÊäΩÂá∫„Åó„Åæ„Åô„ÄÇÂêçÂâçÁ©∫ÈñìÔºànamespaceÔºâ „Å®„ÅØ„ÄÅÂêÑË¶ÅÁ¥†„Å´‰∏ÄÊÑè„ÅÆË≠òÂà•Â≠ê„Çí‰ªò‰∏é„Åô„Çã„Åü„ÇÅ„ÅÆÁØÑÂõ≤„ÇíÊåá„Åó„Åæ„Åô„ÄÇÊú¨ÊâãÈ†Ü„Åß„ÅØ„ÄÅ„Ç≥„Éº„Éâ„ÅÆÂèØË™≠ÊÄß„ÇíÈ´ò„ÇÅ„ÇãÁõÆÁöÑ„ÅßÂÆöÁæ©„Åó„Å¶„ÅÑ„Åæ„Åô„ÄÇ

„Åù„ÅÆÂæå„ÄÅ„Éï„Ç£„É´„Çø„É™„É≥„Ç∞„Åó„Åü„Éá„Éº„Çø„Çí Turtle ÂΩ¢Âºè „Åß‰øùÂ≠ò„Åó„Åæ„Åô„ÄÇTurtle „ÅØ RDF „Éá„Éº„Çø„ÇíË°®Áèæ„Åô„Çã„Éï„Ç©„Éº„Éû„ÉÉ„Éà„ÅÆ‰∏Ä„Å§„Åß„ÅÇ„Çä„ÄÅÂèØË™≠ÊÄß„ÅåÈ´ò„Åè„ÄÅSPARQL „ÇØ„Ç®„É™„Å®„ÅÆË¶™ÂíåÊÄß„Å´„ÇÇÂÑ™„Çå„Å¶„ÅÑ„Åæ„Åô„ÄÇ

# „Éï„Ç£„É´„Çø„É™„É≥„Ç∞Áî®„ÅÆ„Ç∞„É©„Éï‰ΩúÊàê
filtered = Graph()

# ÂêçÂâçÁ©∫Èñì„ÅÆÂÆöÁæ©
ns1 = Namespace("http://www.socrata.com/rdf/terms#")
ns2 = Namespace("https://data.cityofnewyork.us/resource/_4ubz-8kkx/")

filtered.bind("ns1", ns1)
filtered.bind("ns2", ns2)

# ÊåáÂÆö„Åï„Çå„Åü„Éó„É≠„Éë„ÉÜ„Ç£„ÅÆ„Åø„Çí„Éï„Ç£„É´„Çø„É™„É≥„Ç∞
for s, p, o in g:
    if p in (ns1.rowID, ns2.dscrpt, ns2.infl_outfl):
        filtered.add((s, p, o))

# „Éï„Ç£„É´„Çø„É™„É≥„Ç∞ÁµêÊûú„Çí„Éï„Ç°„Ç§„É´„Å´‰øùÂ≠ò
filtered.serialize(destination="rows_filtered_100.ttl", format="turtle")

 

Step 2ÔºöHANA Cloud„ÅÆTriple Store„Å´„Éá„Éº„Çø„ÇíÊ†ºÁ¥ç

Ê¨°„Å´„ÄÅÁí∞Â¢ÉÂ§âÊï∞„Åã„ÇâË™çË®ºÊÉÖÂ†±„ÇíË™≠„ÅøËæº„Åø„ÄÅSAP HANA Cloud„Å´Êé•Á∂ö„Åó„Å¶RDF„Éá„Éº„Çø„ÇíTriple Store„Å∏Ê†ºÁ¥ç„Åó„Åæ„Åô„ÄÇ

import os
from hdbcli import dbapi
from dotenv import load_dotenv

load_dotenv(override=True)

def get_hana_connection():
    conn = dbapi.connect(
        address=os.getenv("HANA_ADDRESS"),
        port=int(os.getenv("HANA_PORT")),
        user=os.getenv("HANA_USER"),
        password=os.getenv("HANA_PASSWORD")
    )    
    print("Connected to HANA:", conn.isconnected())
    
    return conn

# HANA„Å®„ÅÆÊé•Á∂ö„ÇíÁ¢∫Á´ã
conn = get_hana_connection()
cursor = conn.cursor()

# RDF„Éï„Ç°„Ç§„É´„ÅÆË™≠„ÅøËæº„Åø
with open(rdf_filename, 'r', encoding='utf-8') as rdf_file:
    rdf_data = rdf_file.read()

# HANA„É≠„Éº„ÉâÁî®„ÅÆ„Éò„ÉÉ„ÉÄ„ÉºË®≠ÂÆö
graphname = 'financial_plan_statements_cashflow_filtered_100'
request_hdrs = (
    'rqx-load-protocol: true\r\n'
    f'rqx-load-filename: {rdf_filename}\r\n'
    f'rqx-load-graphname: {graphname}\r\n'
)

# SPARQL„ÇØ„Ç®„É™„ÅÆÂÆüË°å
cursor.callproc('SPARQL_EXECUTE', (rdf_data, request_hdrs, '', None))
conn.commit()

 

Step 3ÔºöSPARQL„Å´„Çà„Çã„Éá„Éº„ÇøÊ§úÁ¥¢

ÊúÄÂæå„Å´„ÄÅHANA Cloud „ÅÆ Triple Store „Å´Ê†ºÁ¥ç„Åï„Çå„Åü RDF „Éá„Éº„Çø„Çí„ÄÅSPARQL „ÇØ„Ç®„É™„ÇíÁî®„ÅÑ„Å¶Ê§úÁ¥¢„Åó„Åæ„Åô„ÄÇ„Åì„Åì„Åß„ÅØ SPARQL_TABLE „Çí‰ΩøÁî®„Åó„ÄÅSQL Êñá„Åã„Çâ SPARQL „ÇØ„Ç®„É™„ÇíÂÆüË°å„Åó„Å¶„ÅÑ„Åæ„Åô„ÄÇ„Åì„ÅÆÊñπÊ≥ï„Å´„Çà„Çä„ÄÅËø∞Ë™û„Åå dscrpÔºàË™¨ÊòéÔºâ„Åß„ÅÇ„Çã„Éà„É™„Éó„É´„ÅÆ„Åø„Çí„ÉÜ„Éº„Éñ„É´ÂΩ¢Âºè„ÅßÂèñÂæó„Åß„Åç„Åæ„Åô„ÄÇ

‰∏ÄÊñπ„Åß„ÄÅSPARQL_EXECUTE „ÇíÂà©Áî®„Åô„Çå„Å∞„ÄÅSPARQL „ÇØ„Ç®„É™„ÇíÁõ¥Êé•ÂÆüË°å„Åô„Çã„Åì„Å®„ÇÇÂèØËÉΩ„Åß„Åô„ÄÇ„Åü„Å†„Åó„ÄÅ„Åì„Å°„Çâ„ÅØ„É¨„Çπ„Éù„É≥„Çπ„Åå„ÉÜ„Ç≠„Çπ„ÉàÂΩ¢Âºè„ÅßËøî„Åï„Çå„Çã„Åü„ÇÅ„ÄÅ„Éá„Éº„Çø„ÅÆÊõ∏„ÅçËæº„ÅøÂá¶ÁêÜ„Å´ÈÅ©„Åó„Å¶„ÅÑ„Åæ„Åô„ÄÇ

graphname = "financial_plan_statements_cashflow_filtered_100"

sparql = f"""
SELECT ?s ?p ?o
FROM <{graphname}>
WHERE {
  ?s ?p ?o .
  FILTER(STRSTARTS(STR(?p), "https://data.cityofnewyork.us/resource/_4ubz-8kkx/dscrpt"))
}
LIMIT 10
"""

sql = f"""
SELECT * 
FROM SPARQL_TABLE('{sparql}', 'rqx-query-language: sparql')
"""

cur = conn.cursor()
cur.execute(sql)
rows = cur.fetchall()
cur.close()

for row in rows:
    print(row)

‰∏äË®ò„ÇíÂÆüË°å„Åô„Çã„Å®„ÄÅ‰ª•‰∏ã„ÅÆÂá∫ÂäõÁµêÊûú„ÅåÂæó„Çâ„Çå„Åæ„Åô„ÄÇ

‰ª•‰∏ä„Åß„ÄÅHANA Cloud‰∏ä„ÅßRDF„Ç∞„É©„Éï„ÇíÊßãÁØâ„Åó„ÄÅPython„Åã„ÇâSPARQL„ÇØ„Ç®„É™„ÇíÁî®„ÅÑ„Å¶Êìç‰Ωú„Åô„ÇãÊñπÊ≥ï„Çí„ÅîÁ¥π‰ªã„Åó„Åæ„Åó„Åü„ÄÇ

„Åæ„Åü„ÄÅÊúÄËøë„Åß„ÅØËá™ÁÑ∂Ë®ÄË™û„ÇíSPARQL„ÇØ„Ç®„É™„Å´Â§âÊèõ„Åó„Å¶„Åè„Çå„Çã text2sparql „Å®„ÅÑ„ÅÜÊäÄË°ì„ÇÇÊ≥®ÁõÆ„Åï„Çå„Å¶„ÅÑ„Åæ„Åô„ÄÇ„Åì„Çå„Çí‰Ωø„Åà„Å∞„ÄÅ„ÄåÁå´„ÇíÈ£º„Å£„Å¶„ÅÑ„Çã‰∫∫„ÇíÊïô„Åà„Å¶„Äç„ÅÆ„Çà„ÅÜ„Å™Ë≥™Âïè„ÇíÂÖ•Âäõ„Åô„Çã„Å†„Åë„Åß„ÄÅË£èÂÅ¥„ÅßSPARQL„ÅåÁîüÊàê„Åï„Çå„Å¶ÁµêÊûú„ÇíËøî„Åó„Å¶„Åè„Çå„Åæ„Åô„ÄÇ‰ªäÂæå„ÅØ„ÄÅ„Åì„ÅÆ„Çà„ÅÜ„Å™ÁîüÊàêAIÊäÄË°ì„Å®ÁµÑ„ÅøÂêà„Çè„Åõ„Çã„Åì„Å®„Åß„ÄÅ„Åï„Çâ„Å´Áõ¥ÊÑüÁöÑ„Å´„Éä„É¨„ÉÉ„Ç∏„Ç∞„É©„Éï„ÇíÊ¥ªÁî®„Åô„Çã„Åì„Å®„ÅåÊúüÂæÖ„Åï„Çå„Å¶„ÅÑ„Åæ„Åô„ÄÇ

entry.title: CREATING CAPM APPLICATION WITH NODE.JS BY USING S/4 HANA DATABASE - Part 2
entry.content:
Hello Buddies!!

Have you Subscribed to all our pre-requisites for the development?

No üòê!!!

Don't worry let's set it up. Follow the link below!!

https://community.sap.com/t5/technology-blog-posts-by-members/creating-capm-application-with-node-js-by-using-s-4-hana-database/ba-p/14208638

Welcome to next episode of CREATING CAPM APPLICATION WITH NODE.JS BY USING S/4 HANA DATABASE.

In this Episode Lets Create an Capm Application by Using a Template, So that deployment configurations will be added automatically without manual errors.

Step1: Click on the light = icon and select Project from Template > Cap Project. 

 

Step2: Click on next and Fill the details like Project name, Runtime environment. I named my project as zcapm_hanadb.

 

 

 

 

Click on Finish. Hurray our app gets generated in few seconds.

Note: Check whether you are subscribed to Hana cloud, which is already there in prerequisites blog, We have also created a instance for that.

Now make sure your Hana db instance is running.

It would take around 10 to 15 minutes to get to running status.

Now let move to SAP BAS where our application got created.

Step3: Run the application as Right click on app> Open in integrated Terminal > Enter command CDS Watch, check whether all the node modules installed or not. Enter Command

npm install

 

Step4: Next enter the command npm install -g hana-cli. In this we are installing hana cloud Command line interface where we need to push our data into.

 

Now lets work on our Project before we connect with Data Base.

Step5: In folder structure under db >data-model.cds(I have re-named it on my own interest).Name should be filename.cds 

 

Lets create our Structure, In this there should be one Unique key for every entity you have created.

Code:

 

namespace zcapm_hanadb;

entity Products {

      @title : 'Sales

Order Number'

    key id: Integer;

      @title : 'Product Name'

    name: String;

      @title : 'Price'

    price: Decimal;

      @title : 'Description'

    description: String;

      @title : 'Stock left'

    stock: Integer;
}

 

Step 6: In folder structure under srv >cat-service.cds(I have re-named it on my own interest).Name should be filename.cds

 

In this case lets declare our function calls for get and Post. Just function names are declared in this section where we are about to call them in another file.

Important Note: In defining the cds function please remember two main things,

  1. a) function(Get Call)
  2. b) action (Post Call)

Code: 

 

using zcapm_hanadb from '../db/data-model';
service CatalogService{
  entity Products as projection on zcapm_hanadb.Products;
  // get service call
 function fnCatalogGetService(name: String) returns String;
 // Post service call
action fnCreateRecord(id: Integer, name: String, price: Decimal, description:String, stock: Integer) returns String;
}

 

Step 7: In this let's create one more file under srv>cds-service.js (filename.js). 

In this file we will write our node js logic for functions we have declared in cat-service.cds.

Code: 

 

const cds = require('@sap/cds');
const {Products} = cds.entities('zcapm_hanadb');
module.exports = cds.service.impl(async function() {
   //Get call
this.on('fnCatalogGetService', async (req) => {
    const { name } = req.data;
 console.log(name, "Hello World");
// Post call
this.on('fnCreateRecord', async (req) => {
 const { id, name, price, description, stock } = req.data;
console.log("Hello World is working fine");
})
});

 

Now we have created our very basic structure of entity and has given a service name under it. In order to utilize our service lets deploy our app to S/4 Hana DB and call data from it.

Command: cds build (Find there any errors in the terminal)

command: cds watch (Run the app).

 

Note: If you found error message like in above image, then follow below steps.

  1. First enter Ctrl + C (To End the process)
  2. Click = > View > Command Palette.

 

Enter Stop port and select below one.

 

Once it is done, now again enter the cds watch. You will find the screen like below where you you can find your service.

 

Step 8:  Lets connect to our app to S/4 Hana DB.

On the top-left most corner  where our project we have opened, there when you minimize it you will find SAP HANA PROJECTS. Open them.

 

Step 9: Expand our project.

 

Step 10: Under Database Connections we can find the same project name.

Click on the Green socket symbol to bind our project to HDI container (i.e., Hana DB container).

 

  • Bind to an HDI container

 

  • Click on new service instance, it will suggest you a name(you can rename it or use it as it is)

 

 

Note: Make sure your Hana Cloud is running

 

 

On clicking on top of Database Connections click on bind all.

Next Click on Hana HD Container symbol which is on the top of project.

Mean while if you want to know what are all services got generated. Enter the command 

cf services

 

 

 

We can see our instance got reflected in sap BTP as well.

 

 

Application gets open here you can find your container with in built database with the instance we have created.

 

 

Step 11: Our service got binded in the HDI Container and let's deploy our app.

Click on the deploy icon(Rocket icon) under hana projects > your project.

 

Our deployment looks like below screen.

 

Under project > db you can observe all our hana database files got created.

 

Navigate to Hana db explorer, we see our app got deployed. Refresh the page.

 

 

 

 

As our structure is ready let‚Äôs add some data in it.

 

Step 12: Right click on your entity and select import data. Filename should be same as entity name which we have maintained in db>data-model.cds

File Data I Have Uploaded Here..

Id

name

price

Description

stock

1

Widget A

19.99

A useful widget for various tasks

100

2

Widget B

29.99

An advanced widget with additional features

50

3

Widget C

39.99

A premium widget designed for expert users

25

 

 

 

 

In Step3 it automatically reads the table from the data imported.

 

Once you click on Review, this looks like below

Click on import to database

 

 

Hurray! we don‚Äôt have any errors and it's successfully imported.

Now import it to our database table Review > Import data.

 

 

 

 

Now right click and click on Open Data. 

 

As our database is having the data now, we need to have scope to access it in our application.

Lets run the application command: cds watch --profile  hybrid.

Here after we will be using this command as will compile the runtime dependencies.

 

 

 

Error: Data is not loaded let's fix it up!!!

We need to add the shared key access for the cloud foundry

Step 13: Go to btp cockpit and the service instance that we have created during deployment process, Copy it.

 

 

 

Copy the Bold letters as an Instance name and type in with the command in your app

Command: cds bind -2 <instanceName>:SharedDevKey   

 

 

 

 

Instance key also gets appeared on top of hana DB explorer.

Step 14: Next run cds watch --profile hybrid

 

Click on Products and Check your metadata is loaded or not.

 

Hurray!!! My data got loaded successfully.

In next session lets perform CRUD Operations on S/4 Hana data from SAP Fiori app as Front end...Stay Tunedüòâ

References:

https://fioriappslibrary.hana.ondemand.com/sap/fix/externalViewer/

https://community.sap.com/t5/technology-q-a/creating-capm-application-with-node-js-by-using-s-4-hana...

https://help.sap.com/fiori_bs2013/helpdata/en/a7/1564526ba1f25fe10000000a423f68/content.htm?no_cache...


Hope it‚Äôs helpful üòä

Thanks,
Divya MANDAVA.

entry.title: SAP TechEd Berlin 2025: DA263 | SAP HANA Cloud - Advisors and automation
entry.content:
A couple of words about me:

My name is Jinhee Jeong and I‚Äôm a Product Manager for SAP HANA Cloud, with a focus on Intelligent Automation involving various advisors and automation features for cloud database administration and optimization.

My session:

DA263 | SAP HANA Cloud: Advisors and automation   /  Nov 6 (Thursday) 9:00 AM - 11:00 AM CET

What you will learn about:

This hands-on workshop session will transform how you optimize your SAP HANA Cloud databases! Join me as we explore the powerful intelligent advisors available in HANA Cloud Central, where you'll learn to configure and leverage the Elastic Compute Node Advisor, Partition Advisor, and Index Advisor.

This interactive session is designed to give you practical experience in generating intelligent database optimization recommendations that can improve your system performance. We'll dive deep into the configuration process for each advisor, and learn multiple proven approaches for implementing these recommendations.

Whether you're a database administrator, developer, or SAP professional looking to enhance your optimization skills, this workshop will provide you with actionable insights and hands-on techniques you can apply immediately. Don't miss this opportunity to master these essential tools and take your SAP HANA Cloud database performance to the next level!

Other related sessions I recommend:

ST115 | SAP HANA Cloud: The database for business AI

DA817 | What's next for SAP HANA Cloud: Road map and innovation highlights

DA200 | Help future-proof your database landscape with SAP HANA Cloud

DA201 | Accelerating your AI strategy with SAP HANA Cloud

DA202 | Extensibility at scale: Build intelligent applications with SAP HANA Cloud

DA261 | Unlocking AI-driven insights from your business data in SAP HANA Cloud

Related community topic pages:

SAP HANA On-premises and Cloud Databases

Looking forward to seeing you:

Ready to supercharge your SAP HANA Cloud database performance? Register now for this hands-on workshop and discover how to unlock the full potential of HANA Cloud Central's intelligent advisors! Space is limited, so secure your spot today and join fellow SAP professionals in mastering these tools.

Now let's hear from you:

Are you familiar with SAP HANA Cloud? or HANA Cloud Central, the administration tool? Do you have any specific expectations on this hands-on workshop based on your previous experience? Feel free to share your expectations or insights in the comment!

entry.title: SAP CodeJam HANA AI in Porto 2025-09 Recap
entry.content:
At the end of September, we held an SAP CodeJam event in Vila Nova de Gaia, Portugal. The event focused on exploring the foundations of AI applications with the SAP HANA Cloud: Vector Engine and Knowledge Graph Engine.

Thanks to the local host and organizers: @MatheusBrasil , @MRobalinho and the rest of the team...

...and participants!

It was great to have my teammate and fellow developer advocate @qmacro joining us... not only during the lunch break üêü

SAP CodeJam in Porto was the day before the very first SAP Inside Track there, so it was great to share a drink during a Stammtisch after the CodeJam...

 The following day, I had a chance to present the long story of LLM auto completion to AI agents‚Äîwe went in just three years! And invited everyone to join SAP TechEd to watch our Developer Keynote.

November is going to be an intensive month with SAP TechEd on Tour in Berlin, Sydney, and Bengaluru, followed by SAP CodeJams in Melbourne, Singapore, and the Middle East.

I always take the opportunity to experience at least a little bit of the city I am in, so you can see my photos: https://www.instagram.com/p/DPyfRcMDKko/?img_index=1

Would you like to host such an SAP CodeJam?

entry.title: SAP S/4HANA 2025 Release New Functions
entry.content:
• LoB Affected:
  • New Functionality Added:
  • Asset Management
  • Consumer Products
  • Cross Applications
  • Defense & Security
  • Finance
  • Insurance
  • Manufacturing
  • Public Sector
  • R+D/Engineering
  • Retail
  • Sales
  • Service
  • Sourcing and Procurement
  • Supply Chain
  • Utilities

Hello Gurus üôÇ

Today i want to share with you my quick dive into the SAP S/4HANA and SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition 2025, and see what is the most significant new functions added to the newer version exclusively.

Hope this blog be useful for you.

LoB Affected:

  1. Asset Management

  2. Consumer Products

  3. Cross Applications

  4. Defense & Security

  5. Finance

  6. Insurance

  7. Manufacturing

  8. Public Sector

  9. R+D/Engineering

  10. Retail

  11. Sales

  12. Service

  13. Sourcing and Procurement

  14. Supply Chain

  15. Utilities

New Functionality Added:

below table is illustrating what's new of 174 added functionalities per each LoB:

Asset Management

  • Maintenance Management

    1. Harmonized Documents in Maintenance Request Apps: With the Harmonized Document Management (HDM) functionality, you can now harmonize the process of handling attachments across different document management frameworks such as Document Management System (DMS), Generic Object Services (GOS), or Archive Link according to your business requirements.
    2. Recording Cooperation With Other Technicians: With this feature, you can determine that maintenance technicians should only be able to record time for another technician by scanning a QR code presented by that person.
    3. Verification of Maintenance Jobs: With this feature, a maintenance technician who has appropriate authorization, can verify jobs performed by another maintenance technician in the Perform Maintenance Jobs app (F5104A). This way, the maintenance technician who is doing the verification provides a quality check based on the principle of dual control.
    4. QR Code Scan Function for Filters in Find Maintenance Orders App: With this feature, you can fill filter fields in the Find Maintenance Orders (F2175) app by scanning QR codes that contain the corresponding filter values. When you scan a QR code with the scanner in the filter area, the system automatically enters the scanned values into the relevant filter fields and executes the search immediately with the relevant results.
    5. New Filter Parameters for Maintenance Order and Maintenance Notification: This feature enables master data specialists to set up geospatial data on objects based on the phase, subphase, notification and order processing contexts. This will help the maintenance planners, supervisors, and technicians to visualize and manage maintenance activities with greater specificity and accuracy.
    6. Original Final Due Date: With this feature, you can view the original final due date in addition to the previous final due date when the final due date is changed in a maintenance notification or a maintenance order. The original final due date indicates the final due date that was initially determined for a maintenance activity, whereas the previous final due date indicates the final due date before the most recent change. This means that the original value remains visible even when the value is changed several times.
    7. Maintenance Order: Dispatch of Individual Operations: With this feature, you can dispatch operations and suboperations of a maintenance order individually. Previously, this option was only available for additional operations in emergency orders and in the apps for Resource Scheduling.
    8. Billable Maintenance Order: Phase-Based Maintenance Process: With this feature, you can use phase-enabled order types to process billable maintenance orders. However, there are some differences in the approval process for billable orders compared to other order types.
    9. Self-Healing for Partner Inheritance: Partner Inheritance transfers partner functions and details from superior technical objects to child technical objects. Self-healing detects and corrects any inconsistencies, maintaining alignment and data integrity across the technical object hierarchy. This process eliminates manual intervention, reducing administrative overhead and the risk of inconsistencies.

Consumer Products

  • Direct Distribution

    • Last Mile Distribution for Direct Distribution
      • Management of Visit List Schedules: This feature introduces visit list schedules for strategic visit list planning.

Cross Applications

  • Integrated Business Communications

    1. Integrated Business Communications: Enable business users to communicate with customers, suppliers, and service partners through personalized, trackable, and scalable messages leveraging business context. Provide this communication initially through e-mail, with more channels to follow.
    2. Log Extension for Customer/ Supplier EoP Check: This feature enables you to get additional log information on why a certain customer/ supplier couldn't be blocked in the system.
    3. Spool Access Method Q: You can use the access method Q in the SAP spool system to print using print queues.
    4. Flexible Data Provider Integration: With this feature, you can use an external data provider of your choice to search for and populate validated data when creating new business partner records. This saves time when creating and researching new business partners. This function is only available if you have licensed and set up the appropriate external data provider. This feature leverages cloud integration capabilities within the SAP Integration Suite. Pre-generated SAP Cloud Integration content is available for the CDQ data provider from the SAP Business Accelerator Hub. Note: This app is only available for cloud-ready mode.
    5. Data Context in the Extended Framework for Situation Handling: This feature enables you to also use data context in the extended framework for Situation Handling. Data context is business data from business objects involved in a situation instance that can be collected, distributed, and used for advanced analytics. If enabled in a situation type, data context is collected when a situation instance is created, updated, or completed.
    6. Custom SAP Object Types/SAP Object Node Types in Situation Objects: With this feature, you can use custom SAP object types and SAP object node types in situation objects.

Defense & Security

  1. Enhancements for the Critical Equipment: This product feature consists of various enhancements for the critical equipment: Migration for Critical Equipment Dismantling of Critical Equipment Technical Status Aggregation for Multiple Technical Status Profiles.
  2. Remote-to-Remote Server Communication Through the Central System: This feature provides the capability to use the central system to communicate from one remote server to another remote server in the same distributed landscape and then re-distribute the data. This supports the process of relocating technical objects and forwarding the notifications and work orders, assuring consistent data in the system landscape while operating at a remote site working offline in a communication-challenged environment.

Finance

  • Accounting and Financial Close

    • Closing Operations (SAP S/4HANA)
      1. Ad Hoc Set and Item in Selections: With this feature, you can use Ad Hoc Sets and Ad Hoc Items as dimensions in selections and validation rules.
    • Corporate Close (SAP S/4HANA)
      1. Additional Fields for Greenhouse Gas: With this feature you can activate a business function that enables you to process additional fields for greenhouse gas in group reporting.
      2. Additional Fields for Public Sector: With this feature you can activate a business function that enables you to process additional fields from the public sector industries in group reporting.
      3. Additional Fields for Financial Services: With this feature you can activate a business function that enables you to process additional fields from the financial services (FS) industries in group reporting.
      4. Display Master Data Change Log for FS Item: In the Define Financial Statement Items app, you can display a change log which shows all the changes that were done for a financial statement item (FS item).
      5. Release Universal Journal: Support of Prior Periods Mode: The release universal journal task now supports two prior periods modes for the accounting integration with group reporting preparation ledger: One for complete data in prior periods and one for delta data in prior periods.
      6. Cross-Version Balance Validation: With this feature, you can define validation rules that can compare figures between two consolidation versions, for example, Actuals vs Budget.
      7. Overwrite Rule Control Level for Balance Validation: With this feature, you can change the message type from Error to Warning for the balance validation tasks with task category Balance Validation in Accounting in the Define Balance Validation Tasks configuration activity.
      8. Activity-Based Consolidation of Investments: Change of Parent: When you change the parent unit in a consolidation group, the task for activity-based consolidation of investments now automatically posts the required entries. It adjusts the cumulative values of the balance sheet for all consolidation units of the consolidation group without an effect on earnings.
      9. Activity-Based Consolidation of Investments: Distribution of Dividends: When a distribution of dividends is reported, the consolidation process should proceed with the intercompany elimination of the dividends as well as the adjustment of the non-controlling interest (NCI). The intercompany elimination is done by the reclassification task. As of this release, you can report the dividend of an investee on dedicated FS items and the activity 18 (Distribution of Dividends). The C/I task supports the corresponding NCI adjustment based on corresponding reported data and the intercompany elimination result.
    • Financial Accounting (SAP S/4HANA)
      1. AVL Version 2 for Accounting View of Logistics Information
      2. Print/Email Payment Advice with SAP S/4HANA Output Management: This feature enables you to print or email payment advice with SAP S/4HANA Output Management.
    • General Ledger (SAP S/4HANA)
      1. Calculation of Key Figures: With this feature, you can calculate the following additional key figures using the Calculate Key Figures (GADBKFC) report
      2. Depreciation Area for IFX and FAR: With this feature, you can specify depreciation area as an additional selection criteria while executing the following MCA processes: Currency Reclassification (IFX) Restatement (FAR)
    • Revenue and Cost Accounting (SAP S/4HANA)
      1. Fulfillment by External Percentage of Completion: You can fulfill relevant performance obligations (POBs) by the percentage of completion (PoC). In the past, this kind of fulfillment was enabled as manual fulfillment only. Now, a new event type is available for the fulfillment of PoC-based POBs: Event Type = PX (Fulfillment by External PoC). To fulfill POBs with this event type, the sender component must calculate the PoC progress and send a fulfillment revenue accounting item (RAI) with fulfillment information to Revenue Accounting and Reporting (RAR).
      2. Enhancement of the "Reprocess Account Determination" Report: The report Reprocess Account Determination (FARR_REPROCESS_ACCOUNTS) has been enhanced to support more selection fields. Up to now, the selection was made solely by using the revenue accounting contract as a mandatory field. With this enhancement, you can select the following main fields: Revenue Contract Company Code Accounting Principle You need to enter a value in at least one of these fields. Additionally, you can restrict your selection by using the fields Created By, Created On, Last Changed By, and Last Changed On, as well as by excluding completed contracts.
      3. Reference Group ID for Performance Obligations with Start Date Type 4: When fulfillments for performance obligations (POBs) with start date type 4 are canceled (for example, through a partial or full return), a cancellation fulfillment is created. For these cancellation fulfillments, the reference group ID is now stored in the fulfillment database table FARR_D_FULFILLMT. This enhancement allows you to easily identify which fulfillment has been canceled.
      4. Fulfillment by Customer-Specific Event Type: You can fulfill performance obligations (POBs) with a customer-defined fulfillment event type if the event types provided by SAP standard are not sufficient for your business scenarios and you would like to enhance them. Depending on the sender component, you need to trigger the creation of a fulfillment revenue accounting item (RAI) by a certain event and provide the corresponding fulfillment event type in the fulfillment RAI.
      5. Support of Cost-Based POC for Execution Order Items with Itemized Billing: This feature enables you to use cost-based percentage of completion (POC) revenue recognition for execution order items with the Itemized Billing billing relevance. The net value of the execution order item determines the planned revenue used in cost-based revenue calculation. The planned cost is the sum of all planned costs from the maintenance orders that are assigned to the execution order item.
      6. Support of the ‚ÄúRevenue-Based Percentage of Completion‚Äù Method for Fixed Price Execution Order Items: This feature enables you to use revenue-based percentage of completion (POC) revenue recognition for a) fixed price execution order items (with billing relevance Billing on Completion or Billing via Billing Plan After Release) and for b) not-billing relevant execution order items with price items as subitems. The planned revenue used in revenue-based revenue calculation comes from a) the net value of the execution order item or b) the sum of net values of all price items. The planned cost is the sum of all planned costs from the maintenance orders that are assigned to the execution order item.
    • General
      1. SAP S/4HANA Management Accounting Interface for Central Finance: With this feature you can enable online replication for certain postings from Management Accounting, provided both the source system and the Central Finance system run on SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition or SAP S/4HANA 2025 FPS0.
      2. Central Market Segment Reporting: With this feature, you can enable reporting for service documents in your Central Finance system. To do so, the attributed profitability segment from the source system, which includes the service document information, is converted into a real cost object in the posting in the Central Finance System.

  • Billing and Revenue Innovation Management

    • Contract Accounting
      1. Submit to Collection Agency: Automatic Recall by API Collection Agency ‚Äì Confirmation: You can now process the recall of collection items automatically as part of data receipt by API Collection Agency - Confirmation.
      2. Import of Intraday Bank Statements: Using the Transfer Run for Bank Statements (FPB7P), you can now transfer intraday bank statement data. To do so, schedule transfer runs at the desired time intervals. The system only transfers new bank statement information to payment and return lots automatically.
      3. Tracking Outgoing Payments by Using a Unique End-to-End Transaction Reference (UETR) Carried over SWIFT: You can now include a unique end-to-end transaction reference (UETR) in all payment instruction messages carried over SWIFT. When making an outgoing payment by using the xx_CGI_XML_CT payment medium formats delivered by SAP, the system can add the UETR to your credit transfers, enabling you to track the status of your payments via the Global Payment Innovation (GPI) Tracker.
      4. Display of General Ledger Items Simulated and Posted During Write-Off: Previously, this was only possible for mass write-offs using transaction FP04M.
      5. Collection Strategy Added as Selection Parameter to Dunning Proposal Run: When scheduling a dunning proposal run, you can now specify collection strategies for dunning proposals on the Dunning Parameters tab.
      6. Storage of Payment Card ID in Provider Contract Items: A contract item can reference either a payment card stored in the business partner or a one-time payment card managed by the SAP digital payments add-on. You can now create and modify one-time payment card references, represented by tokens, through the SOAP-based API Provider Contract ‚Äì Manage or the BAPIs BAPI_CTRACBILLCONTRACT_CREATE and BAPI_CTRACBILLCONTRACT_CHANGE. These tokens are used to identify the cards within the SAP digital payments add-on.
      7. Reversal of Documents with Direct Transfer to G/L: If you post documents in Contract Accounts Receivable and Payable and update the general ledger directly, you can now also transfer the reversal data directly when you reverse the document in the Reverse Documents app.
      8. Contract Data in the Business Partner Financial Overview App: The detail view in the Business Partner Financial Overview app (F2429) now includes contract master data for each business partner.
    • Convergent Invoicing
      1. Decoupling of Print Relevance from Posting Relevance: With this feature, you can define the print relevance of billing document items independently of their posting relevance. This characteristic is passed on to the related invoicing document item. For example, cost postings, which are not relevant for customer invoices, no longer have to be print relevant.
    • Subscription Order Management
      1. Change Process - Change CC Data: The Change CC Data change process enables you to support usage-based scenarios by allowing you to change SAP Convergent Charging (SAP CC) parameters and cross-catalog mapping version in Subscription Order Management. This change process can only be executed using either the Solution Quotation (A2X) or the Subscription Contract Change Process OData API.
      2. Insights Cards Enabled for Subscription Order Management Apps: Insights cards have been enabled for Subscription Order Management apps that now allow you to make on the fly decisions by providing a summarized view of critical business data. The data view is tailored to fit your specific needs and is equipped with contextual navigation to the necessary apps.
      3. Target Quantity in Master Agreement: The master agreement in Subscription Order Management has been enhanced with a target quantity and a released quantity. These fields enable you to perform a partial release of the total quantity of a specific product by defining the target quantity in the master agreement, and consuming part of this quantity in the resultant call-off document. The released quantity is updated in the master agreement based on the ordered quantities in the linked call-off documents.
      4. Rerating of Shared Allowances: The rerating of shared allowances has been enabled in SAP Convergent Charging. To be able to make use of the rerating feature for subscription contracts, the following checks have now been implemented in Subscription Order Management: You must add a business partner to a sharing group. This sharing group can then only be used for this business partner. You can only use a single sharing group ID for all items within a single subscription contract. All products used in a subscription contract must either support rerating or not support rerating. A combination of both is not supported for the rerating feature. You can have only one contributor contract in a sharing group, which is responsible for creating shared allowances. You can, however, have multiple member contracts within a single sharing group.
      5. Subscription with Recurring Delivery of Physical Products: You can now have subscriptions that include the recurring delivery of physical goods or consumables. In such a scenario, the products can be modeled into a bundle or BOM with a subscription product as the main item and the sales items that require recurring delivery as the subitems. In the subscription order or solution quotation, delivery plan lines for the sales items that require recurring delivery can be created based on a delivery frequency and the period. In this scenario the entire product hierarchy including the one-time and recurring sales items are copied to the subscription contact. From the subscription contract based on the delivery plan creation of sales orders are triggered on a periodic basis.

  • Governance, Risk and Compliance for Finance

    • International Trade
      1. Additional Simulation Functionality for AI-Assisted Trade Classification Proposals with Fuzzy Search: With this feature, you can use a new simulation report to schedule the simulation of trade classification proposals with fuzzy search.
      2. New International Trade Compliance Status for Purchase Orders and Purchase Scheduling Agreements: With this feature, a Trade Compliance specialist can check for each product and partner in the purchase order and the purchase scheduling agreement that all legal requirements with regard to Embargo, Sanctioned Party Lists, and Legal Control are fulfilled. This means that dedicated statuses in purchase order documents and purchase scheduling agreements suppress follow-on processes when documents are blocked. In addition, statuses are visible in purchase order documents and purchase scheduling agreements. Note The dedicated statuses for International Trade replace the use of the On Hold status in the purchase order.
      3.
